description: A tropical fruit with a knobby, greenish skin and sweet, creamy white flesh segmented around numerous black seeds. It has a custard-like texture and flavor.
healthBenefits: Good source of Vitamin C, boosting the immune system.
Contains Vitamin B6, important for brain health and development.
Rich in potassium, which helps regulate blood pressure.
Provides dietary fiber, aiding in digestion.

potentialAllergies.name: Seed Toxicity
potentialAllergies.details: Custard apple seeds contain neurotoxins and should not be consumed. Always remove seeds.

cultivationProcess:
Step-by-Step Growing Guide:
1. Climate: Tropical and subtropical, requires warm temperatures and is sensitive to frost.
2. Soil: Well-drained, fertile soil with good organic matter. Tolerates a range of soil types but prefers pH 6.0-7.5.
3. Propagation: Primarily by seeds, which germinate readily. Grafting is used for superior varieties.
4. Planting: Plant in full sun. Trees can grow quite large.
5. Watering: Regular watering is needed, especially for young trees and during dry periods. Avoid waterlogging.
6. Fertilizing: Apply balanced fertilizer during growth periods.
7. Pollination: May require hand pollination in some areas for good fruit set due to dichogamy (male and female parts mature at different times).
8. Harvesting: Fruits are harvested when they are mature (skin turns lighter green, segments slightly separate) but still firm. They ripen quickly off the tree.
growthDuration: Seedling trees may bear fruit in 3-5 years. Fruit ripens 3-4 months after flowering.
sustainabilityTips: Store unripe custard apples at room temperature until they yield to gentle pressure. Ripe fruit can be refrigerated for 1-2 days.
The fruit is typically broken open, and the fleshy segments are eaten, spitting out the seeds.
Compost the skin and discarded seeds.
carbonFootprintInfo: Moderate, typical for tropical fruits needing specific climates and transport (0.8-1.5 kg CO2e/kg).

staticRecipes.name: Eating Fresh Custard Apple
staticRecipes.description: The most common way to enjoy this fruit is by eating its creamy flesh directly.
steps: Select a custard apple that yields slightly to gentle pressure.
Gently break or cut the fruit open. The segments of creamy white flesh will be visible, each surrounding a black seed.
Scoop out the fleshy segments with a spoon or your fingers. Eat the flesh and discard the black seeds (do not eat the seeds).
The skin is not typically eaten.

staticRecipes.name: Custard Apple (Sitaphal) Milkshake
staticRecipes.description: A delicious and creamy milkshake made from the pulp of custard apple.
ingredients: Pulp of 1-2 ripe custard apples (seeds removed)
1-2 tbsp sugar (or to taste, custard apples are quite sweet)
steps: Carefully scoop out the flesh from the ripe custard apple and remove all black seeds. This might take some patience.
Combine the deseeded custard apple pulp, chilled milk, sugar, and cardamom powder (if using) in a blender.
Add ice cubes and blend again briefly.
Pour into glasses and serve immediately.

staticRecipes.name: Custard Apple Rabri (Sitaphal Rabri)
staticRecipes.description: A rich Indian dessert where custard apple pulp is added to thickened, sweetened milk.
ingredients: Pulp of 2 ripe custard apples (seeds removed)
2 tbsp chopped mixed nuts (almonds, pistachios) for garnish
steps: In a heavy, wide pan, bring the milk to a boil. Reduce heat to medium-low.

Simmer the milk, stirring frequently to prevent scorching and a skin from forming on top. Scrape the sides of the pan regularly and add the collected cream back into the milk. Continue to simmer until the milk reduces to about half its original volume and thickens (this can take 30-45 minutes).
Add sugar and saffron (if using). Stir until the sugar dissolves completely.
Remove from heat and let the thickened milk (rabri) cool down completely.
Once cooled, gently fold in the deseeded custard apple pulp.
Chill in the refrigerator for at least 2-3 hours.
Serve chilled, garnished with chopped nuts.
